channel.title: Heat
channel.description:
A container with 300g of water is heated up. The water was originally warmed for 50s and then the temperature was measured in 30s intervals. The measurements are presented in the table below:
Time(s) [50] [80] [110] [140] [170] [200] Temp (C*) [37] [50] [62] [73] [84] [92]
a) Make a graph of temperature as a function of time. How far can you extrapolate? b) What was the temperature of the water at the beginning of the heating process? c) Guess what was the temperature of water at 300s
Me: a) For the extrapolation I would've guessed that to the point where the water reaches 100C since after that it changes into gas. Y/N? b) I have no clue about this. ??? c) There is no water at 300s because it's all gas so 0C

item.title: Heat
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

At 100C the water doesn’t all at once immediately go into gas.

Do you have a graphing calculator?

Read full topic

item.title: Heat
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

Eh Pretty Easy:

c) There is no water at 300s because it’s all gas so 0C

there is water, just not in liquid form

0C would make no sense… cuz then it would be liquid

Read full topic

item.title: Heat
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

b. If you have the function you are able to find out what the temperature was at Time 0.

Read full topic

item.title: Heat

item.description:

A container with 300g of water is heated up. The water was originally warmed for 50s and then the temperature was measured in 30s intervals. The measurements are presented in the table below:

b) I have no clue about this. ???
